content.text: Measure and record the length \(l_0\) of the spring without any load
Suspend the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass from the spring
Measure and record the stretched length \(l_1\) of the spring
Calculate the extension \(e_1\) of the spring using the equation \(e_1 = (l_1 - l_0)\)
Determine a value for \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{m}{e_1}\) , where \(m = 100 \text{g}\)
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 1.1 and 1.2
The spring has already been set up for you
Fig. 1.2
Place the object \(\mathbf{X}\) with its centre at the mark on the metre rule that is \(40.0 \text{cm}\) from the end resting on the bench
Explain briefly how you made sure that the object was in the correct position. You may wish to use a diagram
Measure and record the length \(l_{2}\) of the spring
Remove the object \(\mathbf{X}\) . Measure and record the new length \(l_{3}\) of the spring
Determine the change in the extension \(e_{2}\) for the mass at 40.0cm, where \(e_{2} = (l_{2} - l_{3})\)
Calculate the mass \(M\) of the object \(\mathbf{X}\) using your answer to (a)(iv) and (b)(iv) and the equation \(M = k\left(\frac{e_2}{0.40}\right)\)
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.3
Suggest two practical causes of inaccuracy in this experiment
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will determine the mass of an object
Adjust the distance \(d\) between the lamp and the thermometer so that it is approximately 1 cm. You are provided with a spacer to do this
In Table 2.1, record the initial temperature \(\theta\) (with the lamp switched off)
Switch on the lamp
In Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) at 60s intervals until you have a total of 5 values up to \(t = 240 \text{s}\)
Switch off the lamp
Replace the white card with the piece of black card, making sure that it makes good contact with the thermometer bulb
Repeat step (i)
When the thermometer has cooled down, repeat steps (ii) and (iii)
Complete the column headings in the table
Calculate the overall temperature change for each card after 240s
white card: temperature change =
black card: temperature change =
Determine which surface, white or black, absorbs thermal radiation more efficiently. State the experimental evidence for your choice
surface
evidence
A student suggests that the rate of temperature rise will be greater at the beginning of the experiment than towards the end
Do your results support this? Justify your answer with reference to your data for black card
statement
justification
Another IGCSE student wants to repeat your experiment

Suggest one precaution with the apparatus which she should take to make the comparison between white and black surfaces a fair one. Explain why not taking this precaution might cause the test to be unfair
precaution
explanation
In this experiment, you will investigate how different surfaces absorb thermal radiation
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. The apparatus is set up for you
A screen is provided to the side of the lamp in order to shield your eyes from direct glare. Do not place it between the lamp and the thermometer
On Fig. 3.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter correctly connected to measure the potential difference across the lamp
Connect the voltmeter as described in (i)
Adjust the position of the crocodile clip on the resistance wire to give a voltmeter reading of 1.0V
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the potential difference \(V\) and the current \(I\)
Repeat (i) and (ii) for 3 more positions of the crocodile clip giving larger values of potential difference. Include the maximum length of wire
Switch off
Switch on
Complete the column headings in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of the lamp at each potential difference using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
An IGCSE student suggests that the resistance of a lamp stays the same whatever its temperature
State whether your findings support this suggestion. Justify your answer, using your results and your observations during the experiment
statement
justification
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a lamp
The apparatus has been set out for you as shown in Fig. 3.1
Set the object distance \(u\) to \(0.200 \text{m}\)
Place the screen near the lens. Move the screen until a sharp image of the object is seen on the screen
Carefully measure, and record in Table 4.1, the image distance \(v\) in metres
Repeat steps (ii) and (iii) for object distances \(u\) of \(0.250 \text{m}\), \(0.350 \text{m}\), \(0.450 \text{m}\) and \(0.600 \text{m}\)
Calculate the values of \(\frac{1}{\nu}\) and record them in the table
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{\nu} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((y\text{-axis})\) against \(\frac{1}{u} /\frac{1}{\mathrm{m}}\) \((x\text{-axis}).\) Begin both axes at the origin
The scale must allow the best-fit line, when extended beyond the range of the data, cross both axes
From the graph, determine the value \(p\) of \(\frac{1}{\nu}\) when \(\frac{1}{\nu}\) is zero (the \(x\)-intercept)
From the graph, determine the value \(q\) of \(\frac{1}{\nu}\) when \(\frac{1}{\nu}\) is zero (the \(y\)-intercept)
Calculate \(z\) , where \(z\) is the average of \(p\) and \(q\)
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens where \(f = \frac{1}{Z}\)
f =
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
